Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The STEM Pathways Program at the Massachusetts College of Liberal Arts (MCLA) provides scholarships for academically talented students in financial need who are pursing bachelor's degrees in STEM disciplines at MCLA. The scholarship program supports full-time students majoring in biology, physics, chemistry, environmental studies, computer science, or mathematics. The program awards annual scholarships to students who meet financial need and academic merit criteria. A total of 32 scholarships are planned over a five-year period in The STEM Pathways Program. The STEM Pathways Program allows MCLA to offer scholarships to directly address an area of national concern: the shortage of US graduates trained in STEM related fields. Scholarships for academically strong STEM students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, have an impact on the number of STEM graduates prepared to help national, regional, and local companies. Talented STEM graduates help US industries to compete and innovate in a global economy.

The STEM Pathways Program builds on resources available at the Center for Science and Innovation at MCLA. The Center includes an incubator laboratory providing opportunities for students to achieve experience working with local life science companies. The STEM Pathways Program recruits applicants through open house events, activities for accepted students, partnerships with regional schools, and collaborations with admissions counselors. The STEM Pathways Program includes a range of program activities intended to insure that scholarship recipients complete their STEM degree programs and are able to succeed in joining the STEM workforce. Scholarship awardees are co-located within the dorms during their first year, allowing them to build a strong support network from the beginning of their college experience. STEM faculty host an introductory meeting at the start of each semester to welcome students back and announce program opportunities. Students meet monthly with a peer mentor to discuss program challenges, strategies, and opportunities. STEM departments host a social event on the last Friday of each month allowing STEM faculty to interact informally with students. STEM student support includes tutors and interaction with associates in the Writing Center trained to assist with technical writing assignments and reports. STEM students at MCLA have optional research opportunities supervised by MCLA faculty, and the possibility of internships with regional industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the STEM Pathway Scholarship Program fell into four categories: 1) improve educational opportunities for students, 2) increase the retention of students to degree achievement, 3) improve student support programs, and 4) increase numbers of well-educated and skilled employees in technical areas of national need. Our program provided scholarships to students that obtained and maintained academic success and had financial need. Beyond financial support, we provided events around academics and career awareness as well as social activities to foster cohesion among the STEM Scholars.  During the length of this grant we awarded scholarships to 42 students.  Eleven students lost their scholarship due to grades.  Of these 11, three stayed at MCLA to graduate and the other eight left the college.  25 of the students have graduated and the final six will graduate in May 2020.  Our retention rate of freshman S-STEM scholarship students versus reshman STEM students without scholarships was 90.5% vs 73.5% from 1st to 2nd year, 71.4% vs 47.8% from 2nd to 3rd year, and 76.2% vs 29.8% from 3rd to 4th year.  Our graduation rate was 47.1% vs 41.5%.  We have post graduate information on 16 of the 25 graduates. Of these sixteen, fourteen are working in STEM related fields or attending a STEM graduate program. 

Part of our program involved providing a support system to our students in the program. We attempted this in multiple ways. Throughout the grant, we monitored our students GPA's, and we met with students who were struggling. We also hired STEM Mentors, who were upper level STEM majors that held office hours to answer general questions about college, a STEM Writing tutor, who would help students with technical writing, and STEM tutors, who would help out with specific courses or general suggestions for being successful in college. The following year, we were able to hire students from the program to serve as STEM Mentors. These students, developed novel ideas for social activities, including video game nights and tours of science labs. We found that having STEM mentors from within the program was more successful because they had a better idea of the common issues that the students in this program faced. 

During the lifetime of the grant, we attempted several different types of social and career related events. Initially, we held evening meetings, but the attendance was lower than we liked. After speaking with students who were in the program but not attending the social events, we found that many were working jobs at night, participating in a collegiate sport, or working on homework, and they did not feel that they had the time to attend. To help with this, we also encouraged students in the STEM Pathways grant to participate in events held by different STEM majors. We kept a calendar online for the students of events from different STEM departments and clubs, and required that the students attended two of these per semester.  This allowed the students more agency in choosing activities that aligned with their interests, as well as working around schedules that often included jobs, athletics, clubs, and heavy course loads. Our most popular social event involved science trivia nights. The faculty ran the trivia, and the students would break into teams. Students engaged with each other more during these events, and reported especially enjoying the trivia nights.

In addition, fifteen of our STEM scholars conducted independent research and presented their work at a research conference, including MCLA’s Undergraduate Research Conference, The Northeast Regional COPLAC conference, and the annual National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR).  Several STEM scholars also established a Student Innovation lab at MCLA which provided a space for students to work on computer science/science projects such as creating virtual reality learning tools.

 Our program was successful. We awarded scholarships to 42 students with 31 of them receiving the scholarship through graduation.  A majority of the scholarship recipients have gone onto graduate school or employment in a STEM field. The retention rates were vastly improved for students in the program as compared with other STEM students at our institution. This grant improved educational access for STEM students with financial need, improved graduation and retention rates, encouraged the students to be more involved in STEM departments and clubs, and helped establish a cohort for the students.
